title: Autism traits quick screen
description: A short self check for social communication and sensory patterns.

questions.text: Small sounds or details grab my attention more than they do for other people.
I focus on details more than the overall picture.
In groups, following multiple conversations feels hard.
Switching between tasks or topics feels hard.
I miss hints or implied meaning in conversation.
I find facial expressions hard to read.
I struggle to imagine how a situation seems from someone elseâ€™s point of view.
I notice patterns in things more than other people do.
New social situations feel stressful or confusing.
Making new friends feels hard.

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about an autism assessment is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggest a GP chat right now might not be necessary. However, if symptoms start to affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

title: Attention and impulsivity quick screen
description: A short self check for attention, organisation, and restlessness over the last 6 months.

questions.text: I start tasks, then struggle to finish the last details.
I struggle to organise tasks that need planning.
I forget appointments or obligations.
I put off tasks that need sustained focus.
When sat for a while, I fidget or feel restless.
I feel driven, like slowing down is hard.

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about an ADHD assessment is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggest a GP chat right now might not be necessary. However, if symptoms start to affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

title: Mood elevation quick screen
description: A short self check for periods of elevated or irritable mood and changes in energy.

questions.text: I had a period where I felt unusually high, upbeat, or overly confident.
I had a period where I felt unusually irritable, with more arguments or snapping.
I needed much less sleep and still felt full of energy.
I talked more than usual, or felt pressure to keep talking.
My thoughts raced, or I jumped between ideas quickly.
I got distracted more easily than usual.
I had much more energy than usual.
I became more active, busy, or productive than usual.
I became more social than usual, with more calls, messages, or plans.
My interest in sex increased a lot compared to usual.
I took risks that later caused problems, such as spending, driving, or big decisions.
Other people said my behaviour seemed unusual or excessive.
I felt more goal driven, with strong urges to start new projects.
Several of the Yes answers happened in the same period of time.
How much did this affect work, social life, or home life.

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about an bipolar disorder assessment is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggest a GP chat right now might not be necessary. However, if symptoms start to affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

questions.text: Little interest or pleasure in doing things.
Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless.
Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much.
Feeling tired or having little energy.
Poor appetite or overeating.
Feeling bad about yourself, or that you are a failure, or have let yourself or your family down.
Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television.
Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed. Or the opposite, being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual.
Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself in some way.

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about a depression assessment is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggest a GP chat right now might not be necessary. However, if symptoms start to affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

questions.text: Feeling nervous, anxious or on edge.
Not being able to stop or control worrying.
Worrying too much about different things.
Trouble relaxing.
Being so restless that it is hard to sit still.
Becoming easily annoyed or irritable.
Feeling afraid as if something awful might happen.

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about your anxiety symptoms is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggest a GP chat right now might not be necessary. However, if symptoms start to affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

questions.text: About how often did you feel tired out for no good reason?
About how often did you feel nervous?
About how often did you feel so nervous that nothing could calm you down?
About how often did you feel hopeless?
About how often did you feel restless or fidgety?
About how often did you feel so restless you could not sit still?
About how often did you feel depressed?
About how often did you feel that everything was an effort?
About how often did you feel so sad that nothing could cheer you up?
About how often did you feel worthless?

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about stress and general mood is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggest a GP chat right now might not be necessary. However, if symptoms start to affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

questions.text: About how often did you feel nervous?
About how often did you feel hopeless?
About how often did you feel restless or fidgety?
About how often did you feel so depressed that nothing could cheer you up?
About how often did you feel that everything was an effort?
About how often did you feel worthless?

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about distress is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggest a GP chat right now might not be necessary. However, if symptoms start to affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

questions.text: How often do you have a drink containing alcohol?
How many units of alcohol do you drink on a typical day when you are drinking?
How often have you had 6 or more units if female, or 8 or more if male, on a single occasion in the last year?

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about your alcohol use is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggest a GP chat right now might not be necessary. However, if symptoms start to affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

title: PHQ-2
description: Ultra-short depression symptom screen (items 1 and 2 from PHQ-9).

questions.text: Little interest or pleasure in doing things.
Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless.

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about your mood is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggests a GP chat right now might not be necessary. If symptoms affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

title: GAD-2
description: Ultra-short general anxiety symptom screen (items 1 and 2 from GAD-7).

questions.text: Feeling nervous, anxious or on edge.
Not being able to stop or control worrying.

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about anxiety symptoms is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggests a GP chat right now might not be necessary. If symptoms affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

title: PC-PTSD-5
description: Primary care PTSD screen. Answer these only if you have experienced a traumatic event.

questions.text: Have you had nightmares about the event or thought about the event when you did not want to?
Tried hard not to think about the event or went out of your way to avoid situations that reminded you of the event?
Been constantly on guard, watchful, or easily startled?
Felt numb or detached from people, activities, or your surroundings?
Felt guilty or unable to stop blaming yourself or others for the event or problems the event caused?

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about trauma symptoms is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggests a GP chat right now might not be necessary. If symptoms affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

questions.text: Repeated, disturbing, and unwanted memories of the stressful experience.
Repeated, disturbing dreams of the stressful experience.
Suddenly feeling or acting as if the stressful experience were actually happening again (as if you were actually back there reliving it).
Feeling very upset when something reminded you of the stressful experience.
Having strong physical reactions when something reminded you of the stressful experience (for example, heart pounding, trouble breathing, sweating).
Avoiding memories, thoughts, or feelings related to the stressful experience.
Avoiding external reminders of the stressful experience (for example, people, places, conversations, activities, objects, or situations).
Trouble remembering important parts of the stressful experience.

Having strong negative beliefs about yourself, other people, or the world (for example, having thoughts such as: I am bad, there is something seriously wrong with me, no one can be trusted, the world is completely dangerous).
Blaming yourself or someone else for the stressful experience or what happened after it.
Having strong negative feelings such as fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame.
Loss of interest in activities that you used to enjoy.
Feeling distant or cut off from other people.
Trouble experiencing positive feelings (for example, being unable to feel happiness or have loving feelings for people close to you).
Irritable behaviour, angry outbursts, or acting aggressively.
Taking too many risks or doing things that could cause you harm.
Being â€œsuperalertâ€ or watchful or on guard.
Feeling jumpy or easily startled.
Having difficulty concentrating.
Trouble falling or staying asleep.

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about trauma symptoms is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggests a GP chat right now might not be necessary. If symptoms affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

title: Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (low self-esteem screen)
description: Scores here measure low self-esteem risk. Higher scores mean lower self-esteem.

questions.text: On the whole, I am satisfied with myself.
At times I think I am no good at all.
I feel that I have a number of good qualities.
I am able to do things as well as most other people.
I feel I do not have much to be proud of.
I certainly feel useless at times.
I feel that I'm a person of worth, at least on an equal plane with others.
I wish I could have more respect for myself.
All in all, I am inclined to feel that I am a failure.
I take a positive attitude toward myself.

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates low self-esteem risk. A GP chat or talking-therapy referral is worth considering if this affects daily life.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggests low self-esteem risk is lower. If this affects daily life, support still makes sense.

title: CES-D

questions.text: I was bothered by things that usually don't bother me.

title: WHO ASRS v1.1 (6-item)
description: Adult ADHD self-report screener. Part A of the WHO ASRS.

questions.text: How often do you have trouble wrapping up the final details of a project, once the challenging parts have been done?
How often do you have difficulty getting things in order when you have to do a task that requires organization?
How often do you have problems remembering appointments or obligations?
When you have a task that requires a lot of thought, how often do you avoid or delay getting started?
How often do you fidget or squirm with your hands or feet when you have to sit down for a long time?
How often do you feel overly active and compelled to do things, like you were driven by a motor?

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about ADHD assessment is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggests a GP chat right now might not be necessary. If symptoms affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

title: SCOFF
description: Brief eating disorder screen (Sick, Control, One stone, Fat, Food).

questions.text: Do you make yourself Sick because you feel uncomfortably full?
Do you worry you have lost Control over how much you eat?
Have you recently lost more than One stone (14 lb / 6.4 kg) in a 3-month period?
Do you believe yourself to be Fat when others say you are too thin?
Would you say that Food dominates your life?

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about eating and body image is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggests a GP chat right now might not be necessary. If eating or body image affects daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

title: OCI-4
description: Ultra-brief OCD screening scale (4 items from OCI-R).

questions.text: I get upset if objects are not arranged properly.
I repeatedly check doors, windows, drawers, etc.
I sometimes have to wash or clean myself simply because I feel contaminated.
I frequently get nasty thoughts and have difficulty in getting rid of them.

scoring.positiveText: Your score indicates that a GP chat about OCD assessment is worth considering.
scoring.negativeText: Your score suggests a GP chat right now might not be necessary. If obsessions or compulsions affect daily life, a GP chat still makes sense.

title: C-SSRS (Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale)
description: Brief screening for suicidal ideation and behavior. Some questions only appear depending on your answers.
disclaimer: Screening only. Not a diagnosis. If you are in crisis, please reach out to a crisis line or emergency services.

crisisResource.label: Get help now
crisisResource.line: 116 123 (Samaritans, 24/7) â€“ NHS advice and more numbers

questions.text: Have you wished you were dead or wished you could go to sleep and not wake up?
Have you actually had any thoughts of killing yourself?
Have you been thinking about how you might do this?
Have you had these thoughts and had some intention of acting on them?
Have you started to work out or worked out the details of how to kill yourself? Do you intend to carry out this plan?

Have you done anything, started to do anything, or prepared to do anything to end your life? (For example: collected pills, gotten a gun, given valuables away, written a note, or taken pills / held a gun / gone somewhere to attempt.)

levels.summary: You indicated thoughts or actions about ending your life. Please reach out to a crisis line or emergency services now. You are not alone.
details: Crisis support is available 24/7. Use the resource below.

levels.summary: You indicated having a plan and intent. Please reach out to a crisis line or a mental health professional today.
details: Support is available 24/7. Use the resource below.

levels.summary: You indicated some intention to act on these thoughts. Speaking with a mental health professional or your GP soon is important.
details: If at any point you feel in crisis, use the resource below.

levels.summary: You indicated some thoughts about suicide. A chat with your GP or a mental health professional can help.
details: If things get harder, reach out to the resource below.

levels.summary: You indicated some thoughts about suicide. A chat with your GP or a mental health professional can help.
details: If things get harder, reach out to the resource below.

defaultLevel.summary: You did not report current suicidal ideation or behavior.
details: If that changes, reach out to a crisis line or your GP. The resource below is available 24/7.
